Keywords : High Reynolds Number, Turbulent Flow, URANS, OpenFOAM, pimpleFoam
Abstract: Flow past a smooth circular cylinder at high Reynolds number (Re=3.6 x 10
) which
covers the upper-transition regime has been investigated numerically by using Open source Field
Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].
Numerical Simulation
Flow simulation is carried out by using OpenFoam. The physics of the flow is considered as
Page 2:
case. pimpleFoam algorithm uses an inner PISO loop to get an initial solution, which is then under-
relaxed and corrected using an outer SIMPLE loop. This method enables unsteady simulations at
Courant number (Co) numbers larger than 1. In theory, very large Co numbers could be maintained
if a large number of SIMPLE correction loops were applied along with large under-relaxation
factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published
experimental data and numerical results in the supercritical and upper-transition flow regimes, i.e.
Re >10
. The present study should be reliable and useful as an engineering assessment tool for
design work.

Abstract: Flow past a smooth circular cylinder at high Reynolds number (Re=3.6 x 10
) which
covers the upper-transition regime has been investigated numerically by using Open source Field
Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].
Numerical Simulation
Flow simulation is carried out by using OpenFoam. The physics of the flow is considered as
Page 2:
case. pimpleFoam algorithm uses an inner PISO loop to get an initial solution, which is then under-
relaxed and corrected using an outer SIMPLE loop. This method enables unsteady simulations at
Courant number (Co) numbers larger than 1. In theory, very large Co numbers could be maintained
if a large number of SIMPLE correction loops were applied along with large under-relaxation
factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

ordinates of the geometry and also discretization parameters. The blockMeshDict file is located in

Results And Discussion
The flow field around the cylinder is characterized by a fairly large wake behind the
cylinder caused by separation at around mid-point of the upper and lower curvature of the cylinder.
The point of separation is near the expected location.
Figures 4 & 5 show the flow streamlines at different times. The wake formation and its

has been shown in Figure 6.

The computations have been performed at Re = 3.6 x10
, which is the upper-transition flow
regime. The objective is to evaluate the applicability of using a standard high Reynolds number k -ε
model for engineering computations of flow around a smooth circular cylinder in upper-transition
flow regime. Therefore, essential hydrodynamic quantities, such as C
and St, have been
predicted and compared with published experimental data [1, 6, 7, 8, 9] and numerical results [10,

The probe has been inserted at a distance of 3.5 m from the centre of the cylinder behind it
to calculate the velocity. The plot gives the fluctuation of the velocity in y-direction Vs time as
shown if Figure 11.
Initially the fluctuation goes on increases but after some time period it stabilises and
fluctuates between the constant values. By looking at the graph, we can say that the model satisfies
the graph nature as per literature of standard k-ε model. But we can’t say that simulation is write

The values of the parameters are in well agreement with the experimental and literature
hence validation of the numerical model set in the OpenFOAM is correct. And this model can be
used to solve the Industrial problems with proper care on mesh as the model is highly sensitive to

mesh as of the fact that “Poor grid resolution, which becomes increasingly severe as the Reynolds

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published
experimental data and numerical results in the supercritical and upper-transition flow regimes, i.e.
Re >10
. The present study should be reliable and useful as an engineering assessment tool for
design work.

Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].
Numerical Simulation
Flow simulation is carried out by using OpenFoam. The physics of the flow is considered as
Page 2:
case. pimpleFoam algorithm uses an inner PISO loop to get an initial solution, which is then under-
relaxed and corrected using an outer SIMPLE loop. This method enables unsteady simulations at
Courant number (Co) numbers larger than 1. In theory, very large Co numbers could be maintained
if a large number of SIMPLE correction loops were applied along with large under-relaxation
factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Results And Discussion
The flow field around the cylinder is characterized by a fairly large wake behind the
cylinder caused by separation at around mid-point of the upper and lower curvature of the cylinder.
The point of separation is near the expected location.
Figures 4 & 5 show the flow streamlines at different times. The wake formation and its
fluctuation from one side of the central axis to other side is in figure 5 and 6. The wake propagation
has been shown in Figure 6.

The computations have been performed at Re = 3.6 x10
, which is the upper-transition flow
regime. The objective is to evaluate the applicability of using a standard high Reynolds number k -ε
model for engineering computations of flow around a smooth circular cylinder in upper-transition
flow regime. Therefore, essential hydrodynamic quantities, such as C
and St, have been
predicted and compared with published experimental data [1, 6, 7, 8, 9] and numerical results [10,

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published
experimental data and numerical results in the supercritical and upper-transition flow regimes, i.e.
Re >10
. The present study should be reliable and useful as an engineering assessment tool for
design work.

Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. The user wants to simulate a 2D URANS flow past a circular cylinder at Re=3.6e6 using OpenFOAM-v2406 with pimpleFoam and kEpsilon. They provided specific initial and boundary conditions in a JSON format and need the case files structured accordingly.

First, I need to extract the necessary parameters from the research paper. The key details are the Reynolds number, turbulence model (k-epsilon), solver (pimpleFoam), mesh type (structured with y+~300), and validation data (Cd=0.4255, St=0.2864). The initial conditions for U, p, k, and epsilon are given, along with boundary conditions for each field.

Next, I'll structure each OpenFOAM file based on the provided JSON. Starting with the 0 directory files (U, p, k, epsilon, nut), each must have the correct FoamFile header, dimensions, internalField, and boundary conditions. For example, the U file should have a fixedValue at the inlet (left), noSlip on the cylinder, and symmetry on top and bottom.

Then, the system files: controlDict needs to specify pimpleFoam as the application, correct time step, write intervals, and endTime. fvSchemes and fvSolution should align with the pimpleFoam requirements, using Gauss linear schemes for gradients and appropriate solvers for pressure and velocity. The PIMPLE settings in fvSolution should match the transient simulation needs, like correctOuterCorr and nNonOrthogonalCorrectors.

For constant files, turbulenceProperties must select kEpsilon, and transportProperties sets the kinematic viscosity (nu) to achieve the desired Reynolds number. The nut file in 0 directory uses calculated type with wall functions.

I must ensure all boundary conditions from the JSON are accurately translated into each file. For example, epsilon uses epsilonWallFunction on the cylinder, and k uses kqRWallFunction. The symmetry planes for up and down boundaries in U and p. Also, the inletOutlet conditions for k and epsilon on the right boundary.

Validating each file against the JSON specifications is crucial. Check that dimensions match, initial fields are uniform as specified, and all boundaries (left, right, up, down, cylinder, defaultFaces) are correctly assigned. Special attention to the controlDict to ensure application is pimpleFoam, time step control, and correct write formats.

Finally, ensure that all files are present and correctly named in the JSON structure, with keys as filenames and values as the file contents without any markdown or extra text. Avoid any headers like the OpenFOAM comment blocks but include FoamFile headers within each file.

So the mistake is in the "0/p" file's defaultFaces boundary condition. The correct type should be "empty" instead of "patch". So fixing the "0/p" file's defaultFaces to type empty should do it.

The error mentions that the patch type is 'symmetry' but the patchField type is 'noSlip'. Wait, 'noSlip' is typically a boundary condition for velocity (U) on walls. Symmetry patches, on the other hand, are used where the flow is symmetric, and they shouldn't have no-slip conditions because that's for walls. So if the mesh's patch 'cylinder' is set as 'symmetry', but in the U file, the boundary condition for 'cylinder' is 'noSlip', that's a conflict.

So the mesh's patch 'cylinder' is of type 'symmetry', but in the U field, the boundary condition for 'cylinder' is 'noSlip', which is a wall condition. That's the inconsistency.

So to fix this, the user needs to change the boundary condition type in the U file for 'cylinder' from 'noSlip' to 'symmetry' to match the patch type. But since the error indicates the patch type is 'symmetry', the correct fix here is to adjust the U file's boundary condition for 'cylinder' to use a symmetry-compatible type.

Looking at the other files, like 0/p, the cylinder is set to symmetry, which is correct if the mesh's patch is symmetry. The error is in the U file's boundary condition. Therefore, the wrong file is 0/U, and the advice is to change the 'cylinder' boundary's type from 'noSlip' to 'symmetry'.

In 0/p and 0/U, the cylinder's type is 'symmetry'. That's a problem because nutkWallFunction is a wall function, which should be applied to a wall-type patch, not a symmetry patch. The symmetry patch doesn't have the necessary characteristics for a wall function to work correctly. 

So the root cause is that the cylinder patch in the nut file is using a wall function, but the corresponding patch in the mesh (as defined in U, p, etc.) is set to symmetry. To fix this, either the patch type needs to be changed to 'wall' in the mesh, or the boundary condition in nut should be compatible with symmetry. But since the turbulence model likely requires a wall function on the cylinder, changing the patch type to 'wall' in the mesh (i.e., in the U, p, k, epsilon files) would be necessary.
